description: Borrowed from German strollen, a variant of Alemannic German strolchen, from Strolch (“vagabond; rascal”).

entries.meaning: A wandering on foot; an idle and leisurely walk; a ramble.

verbs.description: stroll (third-person singular simple present strolls, present participle strolling, simple past and past participle strolled)

entries.meaning: To wander on foot; to ramble idly or leisurely; to rove.
(intransitive, slang) To walk the streets as a prostitute.
examples: "Nammers?" She'd told him before of some Vietnamese gang pressuring her to stroll for them. / "Don't even ask. You don't want to know."

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To do, obtain, or achieve something in a casual and  effortless way.
examples: My daughter strolled through the exam.
